article.title: Editing and writing in DocBook XML
article.subtitle: Hackweek 21

abstract.para: Our documentation format of choice is DocBook XML. We heard people saying that it is too complicated or too complex. But it has many advantages. And if you understand the way of tagging, it is no rocket science anymore. The purpose of this session is to enable you to edit documentation sources written in DocBook yourself, or to even write/contribute content.

section.title: XML toolchain
section.para: An XML toolchain allows you to do the two most important tasks when working with DocBook:

listitem.para: Validating your document against a schema
Transforming your document into a target format (HTML, PDF, ...)

section.para: Of course, it's not limited to these tasks. Depending on your toolchain and how it is configured, it could offer you additional tasks like to check all links or to perform a spellcheck.
For using a XML toolchain, you could use one of these:

section.title: DocBook's philosophy
section.para: DocBook cares about "semantic", the meaning of a particular object. The layout is something of second nature and added later.
That's why you find in DocBook tag names like filename or example to help the author to markup their text. You won't find tag names like bold, italic, underline, or other layout information.

section.title: DocBook schemas and versions
section.para: Currently, there are two main versions in use:

formalpara.title: Version 4.x
formalpara.para: This is the old version that you can find on some legacy documents. You won't see any major improvements except bugfixes.

formalpara.title: Version 5.x (recommended)
formalpara.para: This is the current version. Any development happens here. If you want to be up-to-date with the latest DocBook schema and be more future-safe, use this version.

section.para: DocBook is a schema. The DocBook schema defines the DocBook element and attribute names and their parent-child relationships. For example, you can't have a title tag without, for example, a chapter tag as parent. The DocBook schema defines not only their names and structure them, it defines also the cardinality (how many tags you can use) and in which order is allowed.

The DocBook schema itself is just a concept. To work with that, you need a schema file. Unfortunately, the DocBook schema file(s) comes in different formats. In most cases, the two most important formats are:

formalpara.title: Document Type Definitions (DTD)
formalpara.para: This is a very old format and was definied together with XML. It is mainly used for DocBook version 4.x.

formalpara.title: RELAX NG (RNG)
formalpara.para: This is a more modern format. It is used for DocBook version 5.x exclusively.

section.title: Working with DocBook documents
section.para: As said before in , the two main tasks for a XML toolchain are:

formalpara.title: Validating
formalpara.para: This means, checking your documents against the rules defined in the DocBook RELAX NG schema.

formalpara.title: Transforming
formalpara.para: This means, converting your DocBook document into a target format. To do this, you need the DocBook XSL stylesheets. These stylesheets are able to convert your DocBook document into (X)HTML, PDF, and a few other formats. It is even possible to customize the DocBook XSL stylesheets or write your own if you want to support other, unsupported formats.
